meanings.definition: To cover up or gloss over faults or wrongdoings.
meanings.sent1: She tried whitewashing her mistake by blaming it on someone else.
meanings.sent2: The company was caught whitewashing their financial records to hide losses.
meanings.sent3: John's attempt at whitewashing his messy room with a single sock on the floor was futile.
meanings.sent4: The politician's speech was like whitewashing a crumbling wall, trying to hide the cracks.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's attempt at whitewashing the student's poor behavior only made the situation worse.

meanings.definition: The act of painting over with whitewash.
meanings.sent1: The old barn needed a whitewashing to look fresh and clean.
meanings.sent2: After the whitewashing, the fence gleamed in the sunlight.
meanings.sent3: The whitewashing of the house made it stand out in the neighborhood.
meanings.sent4: The whitewashing of the statue gave it a new life and beauty.
meanings.sent5: The whitewashing of the walls brightened up the room and made it feel more spacious.

meanings.definition: A practice of casting white actors in roles that were originally intended for people of color.
meanings.sent1: The movie faced criticism for its whitewashing of the main character.
meanings.sent2: Whitewashing in Hollywood has been a controversial issue for many years.
meanings.sent3: The play's whitewashing of the lead role caused a stir among the audience.
meanings.sent4: The director's decision to use whitewashing in the film sparked a debate on diversity.
meanings.sent5: The studio's history of whitewashing roles led to calls for more inclusive casting practices.
